speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: SCENE I. A public place.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Enter MERCUTIO, BENVOLIO, Page, and Servants

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: I pray thee, good Mercutio, let's retire:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: The day is hot, the Capulets abroad,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And, if we meet, we shall not scape a brawl;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: For now, these hot days, is the mad blood stirring.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Thou art like one of those fellows that when he

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: enters the confines of a tavern claps me his sword

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: upon the table and says 'God send me no need of

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: thee!' and by the operation of the second cup draws

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: it on the drawer, when indeed there is no need.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Am I like such a fellow?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Come, come, thou art as hot a Jack in thy mood as

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: any in Italy, and as soon moved to be moody, and as

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: soon moody to be moved.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And what to?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Nay, an there were two such, we should have none

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: shortly, for one would kill the other. Thou! why,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: thou wilt quarrel with a man that hath a hair more,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: or a hair less, in his beard, than thou hast: thou

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: wilt quarrel with a man for cracking nuts, having no

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: other reason but because thou hast hazel eyes: what

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: eye but such an eye would spy out such a quarrel?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Thy head is as fun of quarrels as an egg is full of

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: meat, and yet thy head hath been beaten as addle as

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: an egg for quarrelling: thou hast quarrelled with a

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: man for coughing in the street, because he hath

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: wakened thy dog that hath lain asleep in the sun:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: didst thou not fall out with a tailor for wearing

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: his new doublet before Easter? with another, for

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: tying his new shoes with old riband? and yet thou

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: wilt tutor me from quarrelling!

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: An I were so apt to quarrel as thou art, any man

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: should buy the fee-simple of my life for an hour and a quarter.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: The fee-simple! O simple!

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: By my head, here come the Capulets.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: By my heel, I care not.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Enter TYBALT and others

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Follow me close, for I will speak to them.

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Gentlemen, good den: a word with one of you.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And but one word with one of us? couple it with

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: something; make it a word and a blow.

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: You shall find me apt enough to that, sir, an you

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: will give me occasion.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Could you not take some occasion without giving?

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Mercutio, thou consort'st with Romeo,--

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Consort! what, dost thou make us minstrels? an

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: thou make minstrels of us, look to hear nothing but

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: discords: here's my fiddlestick; here's that shall

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: make you dance. 'Zounds, consort!

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: We talk here in the public haunt of men:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Either withdraw unto some private place,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And reason coldly of your grievances,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Or else depart; here all eyes gaze on us.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Men's eyes were made to look, and let them gaze;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: I will not budge for no man's pleasure, I.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Enter ROMEO

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Well, peace be with you, sir: here comes my man.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: But I'll be hanged, sir, if he wear your livery:

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Marry, go before to field, he'll be your follower;

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Your worship in that sense may call him 'man.'

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Romeo, the hate I bear thee can afford

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: No better term than this,--thou art a villain.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Tybalt, the reason that I have to love thee

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Doth much excuse the appertaining rage

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: To such a greeting: villain am I none;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Therefore farewell; I see thou know'st me not.

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Boy, this shall not excuse the injuries

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: That thou hast done me; therefore turn and draw.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I do protest, I never injured thee,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: But love thee better than thou canst devise,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Till thou shalt know the reason of my love:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And so, good Capulet,--which name I tender

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: As dearly as my own,--be satisfied.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: O calm, dishonourable, vile submission!

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Alla stoccata carries it away.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Draws

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Tybalt, you rat-catcher, will you walk?

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: What wouldst thou have with me?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Good king of cats, nothing but one of your nine

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: lives; that I mean to make bold withal, and as you

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: shall use me hereafter, drybeat the rest of the

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: eight. Will you pluck your sword out of his pitcher

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: by the ears? make haste, lest mine be about your

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: ears ere it be out.

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: I am for you.

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Drawing

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Gentle Mercutio, put thy rapier up.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Come, sir, your passado.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: They fight

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Draw, Benvolio; beat down their weapons.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Gentlemen, for shame, forbear this outrage!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Tybalt, Mercutio, the prince expressly hath

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Forbidden bandying in Verona streets:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Hold, Tybalt! good Mercutio!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: TYBALT under ROMEO's arm stabs MERCUTIO, and flies with his followers

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: I am hurt.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: A plague o' both your houses! I am sped.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Is he gone, and hath nothing?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: What, art thou hurt?

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Ay, ay, a scratch, a scratch; marry, 'tis enough.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Where is my page? Go, villain, fetch a surgeon.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Exit Page

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Courage, man; the hurt cannot be much.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: No, 'tis not so deep as a well, nor so wide as a

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: church-door; but 'tis enough,'twill serve: ask for

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: me to-morrow, and you shall find me a grave man. I

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: am peppered, I warrant, for this world. A plague o'

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: both your houses! 'Zounds, a dog, a rat, a mouse, a

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: cat, to scratch a man to death! a braggart, a

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: rogue, a villain, that fights by the book of

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: arithmetic! Why the devil came you between us? I

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: was hurt under your arm.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: I thought all for the best.

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Help me into some house, Benvolio,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Or I shall faint. A plague o' both your houses!

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: They have made worms' meat of me: I have it,

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: And soundly too: your houses!

speaker: MERCUTIO
text_entry: Exeunt MERCUTIO and BENVOLIO

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: This gentleman, the prince's near ally,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: My very friend, hath got his mortal hurt

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: In my behalf; my reputation stain'd

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: With Tybalt's slander,--Tybalt, that an hour

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Hath been my kinsman! O sweet Juliet,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Thy beauty hath made me effeminate

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And in my temper soften'd valour's steel!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Re-enter BENVOLIO

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: O Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercutio's dead!

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: That gallant spirit hath aspired the clouds,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Which too untimely here did scorn the earth.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: This day's black fate on more days doth depend;

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: This but begins the woe, others must end.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Here comes the furious Tybalt back again.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Alive, in triumph! and Mercutio slain!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Away to heaven, respective lenity,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: And fire-eyed fury be my conduct now!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Re-enter TYBALT

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Now, Tybalt, take the villain back again,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: That late thou gavest me; for Mercutio's soul

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Is but a little way above our heads,

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Staying for thine to keep him company:

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: Either thou, or I, or both, must go with him.

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Thou, wretched boy, that didst consort him here,

speaker: TYBALT
text_entry: Shalt with him hence.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: This shall determine that.

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: They fight; TYBALT falls

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Romeo, away, be gone!

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: The citizens are up, and Tybalt slain.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Stand not amazed: the prince will doom thee death,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: If thou art taken: hence, be gone, away!

speaker: ROMEO
text_entry: O, I am fortune's fool!

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Why dost thou stay?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Exit ROMEO

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Enter Citizens,  and c

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Which way ran he that kill'd Mercutio?

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Tybalt, that murderer, which way ran he?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: There lies that Tybalt.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Up, sir, go with me;

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: I charge thee in the princes name, obey.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Enter Prince, attended; MONTAGUE, CAPULET, their Wives, and others

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Where are the vile beginners of this fray?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: O noble prince, I can discover all

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: The unlucky manage of this fatal brawl:

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: There lies the man, slain by young Romeo,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: That slew thy kinsman, brave Mercutio.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Tybalt, my cousin! O my brother's child!

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: O prince! O cousin! husband! O, the blood is spilt

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: O my dear kinsman! Prince, as thou art true,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: For blood of ours, shed blood of Montague.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: O cousin, cousin!

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Benvolio, who began this bloody fray?

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Tybalt, here slain, whom Romeo's hand did slay;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Romeo that spoke him fair, bade him bethink

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: How nice the quarrel was, and urged withal

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Your high displeasure: all this uttered

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: With gentle breath, calm look, knees humbly bow'd,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Could not take truce with the unruly spleen

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Of Tybalt deaf to peace, but that he tilts

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: With piercing steel at bold Mercutio's breast,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Who all as hot, turns deadly point to point,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And, with a martial scorn, with one hand beats

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Cold death aside, and with the other sends

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: It back to Tybalt, whose dexterity,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Retorts it: Romeo he cries aloud,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: 'Hold, friends! friends, part!' and, swifter than

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: his tongue,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: His agile arm beats down their fatal points,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And 'twixt them rushes; underneath whose arm

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: An envious thrust from Tybalt hit the life

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Of stout Mercutio, and then Tybalt fled;

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: But by and by comes back to Romeo,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Who had but newly entertain'd revenge,

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And to 't they go like lightning, for, ere I

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: Could draw to part them, was stout Tybalt slain.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: And, as he fell, did Romeo turn and fly.

speaker: BENVOLIO
text_entry: This is the truth, or let Benvolio die.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: He is a kinsman to the Montague;

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Affection makes him false; he speaks not true:

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Some twenty of them fought in this black strife,

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: And all those twenty could but kill one life.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: I beg for justice, which thou, prince, must give;

speaker: LADY CAPULET
text_entry: Romeo slew Tybalt, Romeo must not live.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Romeo slew him, he slew Mercutio;

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Who now the price of his dear blood doth owe?

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Not Romeo, prince, he was Mercutio's friend;

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: His fault concludes but what the law should end,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: The life of Tybalt.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: And for that offence

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Immediately we do exile him hence:

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: I have an interest in your hate's proceeding,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: My blood for your rude brawls doth lie a-bleeding;

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: But I'll amerce you with so strong a fine

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: That you shall all repent the loss of mine:

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: I will be deaf to pleading and excuses;

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Nor tears nor prayers shall purchase out abuses:

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Therefore use none: let Romeo hence in haste,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Else, when he's found, that hour is his last.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Bear hence this body and attend our will:

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Mercy but murders, pardoning those that kill.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: Exeunt
